Subsection.Text: A facility or conveyance where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must be designed, constructed and maintained in such a manner that the movement of persons and things within, into and out of it is controlled.
The movement must not present a risk of contamination of the food.

Section.Text: Physical or other effective means must be used to separate incompatible activities in order to prevent contamination of a food.
Physical or other effective means must be used to separate a food from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: anything that presents a risk of contamination of the food;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any food that does not meet the requirements of the Act or these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: anything that is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled in an establishment and not intended or sold for use as food.

Section.MarginalNote: Arrival of certain food at establishment

Subsection.Text: Any food that presents a risk of injury to human health, that is exempted under section 22 from the application of the import requirements that are set out in the Act and these Regulations or that does not meet the requirements that are set out in the Act or these Regulations must be identified as such and placed in a designated area when it arrives at an establishment.
Any measures that are necessary to prevent the food described in subsection (1) from contaminating any other food that is in the establishment must be taken.

An establishment must be equipped with natural or artificial lighting that is appropriate for the food or the food animal that is intended to be slaughtered, as the case may be, and for the activity being conducted.
Any light fixtures in the establishment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and, if necessary to prevent contamination of a food, repeated sanitizing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not present a risk of contamination of the food in the event of breakage.

Section.Text: A facility or conveyance where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must be equipped with a ventilation system that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provides natural or mechanical ventilation with sufficient air exchange to provide clean air and to remove unclean air and odours that might affect the food;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is accessible and, if necessary for its cleaning, maintenance or inspection, is able to be disassembled;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of withstanding repeated cleaning; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: functions as intended.

Subsection.Text: The temperature and humidity level in a facility or conveyance where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must be maintained at levels that are appropriate for the food or the food animal, as the case may be, and for the activity being conducted.
If the facility or conveyance is equipped with a heating, cooling or humidity-control system, the system must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if necessary to prevent contamination of a food, be equipped with instruments to control, indicate and record the temperature and humidity levels;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be accessible and, if necessary for its cleaning, maintenance or inspection, is able to be disassembled;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of withstanding repeated cleaning; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: function as intended.

Section.MarginalNote: Removal and disposal of contaminated materials and waste

Subsection.Text: An establishment must have means for the removal and disposal of contaminated materials and waste and, if necessary to prevent contamination of a food, be equipped with a drainage, sewage and plumbing system that functions as intended.

Contaminated materials and waste must be removed and disposed of at a frequency that is sufficient to prevent contamination of a food and in a manner that does not present a risk of contamination of a food.

If necessary to prevent the contamination of a food, an establishment must be equipped with hand cleaning and sanitizing stations, lavatories, showers, drinking water stations, break rooms or change rooms that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are appropriately equipped and adequate in number and size for the number of persons using them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are located so that they are readily accessible to the persons using them; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and, if necessary to prevent contamination of a food, repeated sanitizing.

Subsection.Text: The hand cleaning and sanitizing stations must permit the effective cleaning of hands.
The lavatories must be located and maintained so that they do not present any risk of contamination of a food.

Section.Text: At the request of an inspector, the inspector must be provided with an area that is readily accessible, appropriately equipped and appropriate in size for the exercise of their powers, and the performance of their duties and functions, under the Act.

Subsection.Text: An establishment in which a meat product or processed egg product is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or in which a food animal is slaughtered must provide an inspector with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a furnished office that is readily accessible, appropriately equipped and appropriate in size for the exercise of their powers and the performance of their duties and functions under the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: lockers and cabinets that are readily accessible and appropriate for the protection and storing of their equipment and documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: access to a lockable storage facility or equipment that is appropriate for the protection, preservation and storing of samples.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Private office, change rooms, etc., for inspector
Subsection.Text: In the case of an establishment in which a food animal is slaughtered, the office referred to in paragraph (1)(a) must be private and the inspector must also be provided with access to a lavatory, a shower and a change room in the establishment.
Any water that might come into contact with a food must be potable, unless it does not present a risk of contamination of the food, and must be protected against contamination.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Steam and ice — contact with food
Subsection.Text: Any steam or ice that might come into contact with a food must be made from water that meets the requirements of subsection (1), unless the steam or ice does not present a risk of contamination of the food.

Any system that supplies water that meets the requirements of subsection (1) must not be cross-connected with any other system, unless measures are taken to eliminate any risk of contamination of a food as a result of the cross-connection.

Any water or other source of hydration that is provided to food animals that are intended to be slaughtered in an establishment must not present a risk of injury to the health of those animals and must not present a risk of contamination of the meat products that may be derived from those animals.

Section.MarginalNote: Supply of water, steam and ice

Subsection.Text: An establishment must be supplied, as appropriate for the food or the food animal that is intended to be slaughtered, as the case may be, and for the activity being conducted, with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: water that is adequate in quantity, temperature, pH and pressure to meet the needs of the establishment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: steam that is adequate in quantity and pressure to meet those needs; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ice that is adequate in quantity to meet those needs.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Treatment of water, steam or ice
Subsection.Text: Any treatment of water, steam or ice must be applied in a manner that does not present a risk of contamination of a food.

Section.Text: Any conveyance that is used to convey a food to or from an establishment and that is unloaded or loaded at the establishment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: must be designed, constructed and maintained to prevent contamination of the food;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: must be constructed of, and maintained using, materials that are suitable for their intended use and, if the materials present a risk of contamination of the food, that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: durable,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and, if necessary to prevent contamination of a food, repeated sanitizing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: free of any noxious constituent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: must be capable of maintaining the temperature and humidity at levels that are appropriate for the food and, if necessary to prevent contamination of the food, be equipped with instruments that control, indicate and record those levels;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: must not contain any animal, other than an animal referred to in paragraph 51(2)(a), any pest control product as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Pest Control Products Act or any other material or substance that presents a risk of contamination of the food; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: must be clean and in a sanitary condition at the time of unloading or loading.

Section.Text: Any unloading and loading of a food or of a food animal that is intended to be slaughtered, from or onto a conveyance at an establishment, must be conducted in a manner that does not present a risk of contamination of a food.

Subsection.Text: Any storing of a food must be conducted in a manner that does not present a risk of contamination of the food.

Any storing of conveyances, equipment, sanitizers, agronomic inputs, chemical agents, starter products, packaging material, labels or any other thing that is used in the manufacturing, preparing, storing, packaging or labelling of a food must be conducted in a manner that does not present a risk of contamination of the food.

In subsection (2), starter products means the materials that are used to start growing fresh fruits or vegetables and includes seeds, seedlings, plants, cuttings, canes, seed potatoes and nursery stock.

Section.Text: Any person who is involved in the manufacturing, preparing, storing, packaging or labelling of a food or in the slaughtering of a food animal must have the competencies and qualifications that are necessary to carry out their duties.

Any person who enters or is in an area where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must wear clothing, footwear and protective coverings, including gloves, a hairnet, a beard net and a smock, that are in good condition, clean and in sanitary condition and that are appropriate for the food and for the activity being conducted.

Any person who enters or is in an area where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must maintain personal cleanliness to prevent contamination of the food, including by cleaning and, if necessary, by sanitizing their hands

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately on entering the area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: immediately after using a lavatory;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: immediately before beginning to conduct the activity; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: at a frequency appropriate for the food and for the activity being conducted.

Section.MarginalNote: Spitting, chewing gum and other acts
Section.Text: Any person who enters or is in an area where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must refrain from spitting, chewing gum, using tobacco products, eating, having unnecessary contact with the food and doing any other act that presents a risk of contamination of the food.

Section.MarginalNote: Objects and substances — risk of contamination
Section.Text: Any person who enters or is in an area where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered must refrain from wearing or using any object or substance that presents a risk of contamination of the food.

Section.MarginalNote: Reporting of disease, illness, symptoms and lesions
Section.Text: Any person who works in an area where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered and who has a disease or illness, symptoms of a disease or illness or an open or infected lesion must report them to the operator.

Section.MarginalNote: Communicable disease and lesions — risk of contamination
Section.Text: The operator must prevent any person who is suffering from, or is a known carrier of, a communicable disease or who has an open or infected lesion from entering or being in an area of an establishment where a food is manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled or where a food animal is slaughtered if the person’s condition presents a risk of contamination of the food.

Subsection.Text: An operator who suspects on reasonable grounds that a food presents a risk of injury to human health or does not meet the requirements of the Act or these Regulations must immediately investigate the matter.
If the investigation establishes that the food presents a risk of injury to human health, the operator must immediately notify the Minister and immediately take action to mitigate the risk.
An operator must prepare, keep and maintain a document that sets out a procedure for receiving, investigating and responding to complaints that are received in relation to a food.

If a complaint is received, the operator must implement the procedure and prepare a document that sets out the details of the complaint, the results of the investigation and the actions taken based on those results and keep it for two years after the day on which the actions are completed.

An operator must prepare, keep and maintain a document that sets out a recall procedure that enables the effective recall of a food, the name of a contact person who is responsible for the procedure and the name of a contact person who is responsible for conducting recalls.
The operator must, at least once every 12 months,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a recall simulation, based on the recall procedure; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prepare a document that sets out the details of how the recall simulation was conducted and the results of the simulation, and keep that document for two years after the day on which the recall simulation is completed.

Subsection.Text: If an operator determines that a food should be recalled because it presents a risk of injury to human health, the operator must immediately notify the Minister.
If a food is the subject of a recall because it presents a risk of injury to human health, the operator must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately implement the recall procedure; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prepare a document that sets out the details of the recall, including any information that substantiates its effectiveness, and keep the document for two years after the day on which the recall is initiated.

Section.Text: The holder of a licence to import must comply with sections 82 to 84 in respect of a food that is imported.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder must prepare, keep and maintain a written preventive control plan that meets the requirements of section 89 for any activity identified in their licence that they conduct in respect of a food or food animal.

Despite subsection (1), a preventive control plan is not required to be prepared, kept or maintained for any activity that the licence holder conducts in respect of a food, other than fish or a meat product, that is exported, unless a certificate or other document referred to in section 48 of the Act is sought in respect of the food.

Despite subsection (1), if a licence holder’s gross sales that are derived from food are $100,000 or less for the 12 months before the day on which they most recently made an application for the issuance, renewal or amendment of a licence, a preventive control plan must be prepared, kept and maintained only for any activity that they conduct in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a food animal, meat product, fish, dairy product, egg, processed egg product or processed fruit or vegetable product that is identified in their licence; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a food in respect of which a certificate or other document referred to in section 48 of the Act is sought.

Section.MarginalNote: Growers or harvesters of fresh fruits or vegetables
Section.Text: Any person who grows or harvests fresh fruits or vegetables must prepare, keep and maintain a written preventive control plan that meets the requirements of section 89 for any activity that they conduct in respect of those fresh fruits or vegetables if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to be exported and a certificate or other document referred to in section 48 of the Act is sought in respect of the fresh fruits or vegetables; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to be sent or conveyed from one province to another and the person’s gross sales that are derived from food are more than $100,000 for the previous 12 months.

Section.Text: Any person who is required to prepare, keep and maintain a preventive control plan must implement that plan.

Subsection.Text: The preventive control plan must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the measures for ensuring that the applicable requirements of sections 201 and 205, subsection 206(1), sections 208, 218, 221, 296, 306, 307, 316, 317, 321, 322, 324 to 326 and 328 are met;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the measures for ensuring that the food is packaged and labelled in a manner that does not contravene subsection 6(1) of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to the applicable requirements of these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the biological, chemical and physical hazards that are identified under subsection 47(1) as presenting a risk of contamination of a food, of the control measures for preventing or eliminating those hazards or reducing them to an acceptable level and of the evidence that the control measures are effective,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the critical control points, of the related control measures and of the evidence that the control measures are effective,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the critical limits for each critical control point,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures for monitoring the critical control points in relation to their critical limits,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the corrective action procedures for each critical control point,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures for verifying that the implementation of the preventive control plan results in compliance with the provisions of the Act and these Regulations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: documents that substantiate that the preventive control plan has been implemented with respect to subparagraphs (i) to (vi); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to the applicable requirements of sections 128 to 136, paragraphs 140(b) and (c) and sections 141 to 144,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the measures for preventing or eliminating a risk of avoidable suffering, injury or death to the food animals during their handling, and of the evidence that those measures are effective,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the measures for preventing or eliminating a risk of avoidable suffering or injury to the food animals during their slaughtering, and of the evidence that those measures are effective,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the performance criteria for evaluating the effectiveness of each of those measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures for monitoring each of those measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the corrective action procedures for each of those measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures for verifying that the implementation of the preventive control plan results in compliance with the provisions of the Act and these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures for auditing, on a regular basis, the outcome of the implementation of the preventive control plan, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: documents that substantiate that the preventive control plan has been implemented with respect to subparagraphs (i) to (vii); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: supporting documents that show evidence of the information recorded under paragraphs (a) and (b), subparagraphs (c)(i) to (vi) and (d)(i) to (vii).

Subsection.Text: Each document referred to in subparagraphs (1)(c)(vii) and (d)(viii) must be kept for two years after the day on which it is prepared.

The preventive control plan of the holder of a licence to slaughter a game animal is not required to include any information specified in subsection (1) other than the information specified in subparagraphs (1)(c)(i) and (d)(i).
The preventive control plan of the holder of a licence to import must also include the information specified in subparagraphs (1)(c)(i) to (vii) in relation to the requirements of section 11.
The preventive control plan of the holder of a licence to export must also include the information specified in subparagraphs (1)(c)(i) to (vii) in relation to the requirements of subsection 15(1).

The preventive control plan of a licence holder who is authorized under subsection 160(3) to conduct a post-mortem examination program or a post-mortem defect management program must also include the information specified in subparagraphs (1)(c)(i) to (vii) and paragraph (1)(e) in relation to that program and must meet the requirements that are set out in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a post-mortem examination, the document entitled Fundamentals of the Post-mortem Examination Program, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a post-mortem defect management program, the document entitled Fundamentals of the Post-mortem Defect Management Program, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: Any person who sends or conveys a food from one province to another, or who imports or exports it, any holder of a licence to slaughter a food animal, to manufacture, process, treat, preserve, grade, store, package or label a food or to store and handle an edible meat product in its imported condition and any person who grows or harvests fresh fruits or vegetables that are to be sent or conveyed from one province to another or exported must, if they provide the food to another person, prepare and keep documents that set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the common name of the food, a lot code or other unique identifier that enables the food to be traced and the name and principal place of business of the person by or for whom the food was manufactured, prepared, produced, stored, packaged or labelled;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: except if they provide the food to another person as a sale at retail, the date on which it was provided and the name and address of the person to whom it was provided;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if they were provided the food by another person, the name and address of that person and the date on which it was provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any food commodity that they incorporated into the food or from which they derived the food and, if they were provided the food commodity by another person, the name and address of that person and the date on which it was provided.

Subsection.Text: Any person who sells a food at retail, other than a restaurant or other similar enterprise that sells the food as a meal or snack, must prepare and keep documents that include the information specified in paragraphs (1)(a), (c) and (d).
The documents referred to in subsections (1) and (2) must be kept for two years after the day on which the food was provided to another person or sold at retail, and must be accessible in Canada.
Any person who has received a request from the Minister for a document referred to in section 90, or any part of such a document, must provide it to the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 24 hours after receipt of the request, or within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any shorter period that is specified by the Minister, if the Minister believes that it is necessary in order to identify or respond to a risk of injury to human health associated with a food commodity, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any longer period that is specified by the Minister, if the Minister believes that the document is not necessary for a recall that is or may be ordered under subsection 19(1) of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if provided electronically, in a single file and in plain text that is capable of being imported into and manipulated by standard commercial software.

Subsection.Text: In paragraph (1)(b), plain text means data that is not encrypted and whose semantic content is available.

Any person referred to in subsection 90(1) or (2) must ensure that a label that bears the information specified in paragraph 90(1)(a) is applied or attached to any food, or accompanies any food, that is provided to another person.
In the case of consumer prepackaged food that is not packaged at retail, the unique identifier referred to in paragraph 90(1)(a) must be a lot code.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a food at the time of its export;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a food, other than a consumer prepackaged food, at the time of its sale at retail; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a prepackaged food described in paragraphs 213(a) to (c) at the time of its sale at retail.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — foods described in paragraphs 219(1)(a) and (b)
Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), any food described in paragraph 219(1)(a) or (b) is not required to be labelled with the common name of the food at the time of its sale at retail.

Despite subsection (1), any food described in section 220 is not required to be labelled with the name and principal place of business of the person by or for whom the food was manufactured, prepared, produced, stored, packaged or labelled.

Section.MarginalNote: Application — import, interprovincial trade and export

Subsection.Text: The requirements of this Part apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any foods that have been imported or any foods that are to be sent or conveyed from one province to another or exported; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any food animals from which meat products that are to be sent or conveyed from one province to another or exported may be derived.

Subsection.Text: The requirements of sections 128 to 136 apply in respect of food animals that are in an establishment that is identified in a licence to slaughter.

Section.Text: Any milk or cream that is used in preparing a dairy product that is to be sent or conveyed from one province to another or exported must meet the applicable requirements of the legislation of the province in which the dairy product is prepared.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder may pasteurize eggs in the shell only if they are graded Canada A or Grade A.
Eggs that are pasteurized in the shell and that are imported must have been graded Grade A before pasteurization.

Section.Text: The holder of a licence to import may import eggs only if the licence holder provides an inspector with an official document issued by the foreign state, in a form approved by the President, that states that the eggs meet the requirements that are set out in the Act and these Regulations.

Section.MarginalNote: Import — Grade C or Grade Nest Run
Section.Text: A licence holder who imports eggs that are graded Grade C or Grade Nest Run must deliver them directly to an establishment where eggs are processed and treated by a licence holder.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection 306(1), a licence holder may import ungraded eggs if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the import, notify the Minister in writing of the quantity of ungraded eggs that are intended to be imported, the date of the import and the name of the licence holder and address of the establishment referred to in paragraph (c);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: package them in a container that is labelled with the expression “Ungraded Eggs” or “oeufs non classifiés”; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: deliver them directly to an establishment where eggs are processed and treated by a licence holder.

Subsection.Text: Any imported ungraded eggs delivered to an establishment referred to in paragraph (1)(c) may be removed from that establishment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the eggs have been processed and treated by a licence holder; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the eggs are delivered directly to another establishment where eggs are processed and treated by a licence holder.

Subsection.Text: Any person who sends or conveys any of the following from one province to another must deliver them to an establishment where eggs are processed and treated by a licence holder:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: eggs that are graded Canada A or Canada B that bear an ink mark that consists of the word “dyed” or “teint” or a deposit of ink that is applied to an egg’s shell by the holder of a licence to grade eggs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: eggs that are graded Canada C;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: eggs that are graded Grade C or Grade Nest Run that are imported; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ungraded eggs that are imported in accordance with subsection 98(1).

Subsection.Text: Any person who sends or conveys eggs that are graded Canada Nest Run from one province to another must deliver them to an establishment where either eggs are graded or eggs are processed and treated by a licence holder.

Despite subsection 306(1), any person may send or convey from one province to another ungraded eggs, other than eggs that are rejected in accordance with subsection 333(1) or eggs that are imported in accordance with subsection 98(1), if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: packages them in a container that is labelled with the expression “Ungraded Eggs” or “oeufs non classifiés”; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: delivers them to an establishment where either eggs are graded or eggs are processed and treated by a licence holder.

Section.Text: If a licence holder applies ink to an egg’s shell, the ink must be fast-drying and indelible and it must not present a risk of injury to human health.
Before sending plastic trays to an egg producer, a licence holder must clean, sanitize and dry them.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder may process and treat eggs only if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are edible;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: do not emit an abnormal odour;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are not mouldy;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have not been in an incubator;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: do not have an internal defect, other than a particle of the oviduct or a blood spot neither of which exceeds 3 mm in diameter;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: are not leakers, except if they become leakers while being transferred to the egg-breaking equipment and they are prepared in a manner that prevents the contamination of the processed egg product; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: are free from dirt and other foreign matter.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Processing and treating processed egg products
Subsection.Text: A licence holder may process and treat processed egg products only if they are derived from eggs that meet the requirements of paragraphs (1)(a) to (g).

A processed egg product that is to be sent or conveyed from one province to another or exported and that is processed or treated in an establishment that is identified in a licence must have been chilled to 4°C or less before being removed from the establishment, if it is a

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: liquid whole egg;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: liquid yolk;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: liquid egg white or liquid albumen;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: liquid whole egg mix;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: liquid yolk mix; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: liquid egg product.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), the Minister may, in writing, authorize any person to remove a processed egg product that has not been chilled to 4°C or less if the Minister is of the opinion that no risk of injury to human health will result.

Section.Text: The holder of a licence to import may import a processed egg product only if the licence holder provides an inspector with an official document issued by the foreign state, in a form approved by the President, that states that the processed egg product meets the requirements that are set out in the Act and these Regulations.

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition — import of mitten crab or puffer fish

Subsection.Text: It is prohibited for a person to import

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a live, freshwater mitten crab of the genus Eriocheir; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a puffer fish of the family Tetraodontidae.

Subsection.Text: Section 19 of the Act does not apply in respect of an import referred to in subsection (1).

Section.MarginalNote: Import of live or raw shellfish

Subsection.Text: The holder of a licence to import may import live or raw shellfish only if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign state in which the shellfish is harvested, manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled, as the case may be, has, at the time the activity is conducted, an inspection system for the shellfish that is recognized under Part 7;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign state from which the shellfish is imported has, at the time of the import, an inspection system for shellfish that is recognized under Part 7; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any establishment where the shellfish was manufactured, prepared, stored, packaged or labelled has, at the time that the activity is conducted and at the time of the import, a system for manufacturing, preparing, storing, packaging or labelling, as the case may be, that complies with an inspection system for shellfish that is recognized under Part 7.

Subsection.Text: The conditions in paragraphs (1)(a) to (c) do not apply in respect of the import of the adductor muscles of scallops or the meat of geoducks.
A licence holder may manufacture, prepare, store, package or label shellfish that is to be exported or sent or conveyed from one province to another only if the shellfish is harvested in an area

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that has been classified under the Canadian Shellfish Sanitation Program and that is not subject to an order prohibiting fishing issued under the Management of Contaminated Fisheries Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is subject to an order prohibiting fishing issued under the Management of Contaminated Fisheries Regulations but the shellfish has been decontaminated in accordance with the decontamination plan submitted in connection with a licence to fish for food purposes issued under those Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The conditions in paragraphs (1)(a) and (b) do not apply in respect of the manufacturing, preparing, storing, packaging or labelling of the adductor muscles of scallops or the meat of geoducks.

Section.Text: A licence holder must protect from dehydration and oxidation all frozen fish that is stored in a conveyance.
The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: apple means a fresh apple for which a grade is prescribed by these Regulations. (pomme)
onion means a fresh onion for which a grade is prescribed by these Regulations. (oignon)
potato means a fresh potato for which a grade is prescribed by these Regulations. (pomme de terre)

Section.MarginalNote: Fresh fruits or vegetables packaged together
Section.Text: The requirements of sections 113 to 121 and 269 — as well as any requirements under Division 2 of Part 10 and Part 12 that apply in respect of fresh fruits or vegetables — do not apply in respect of consumer prepackaged fresh fruits or vegetables if the container contains more than one type of fresh fruit or vegetable but no other food and if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the label that is applied or attached to the container bears the expression “Fresh Pack” or “emballage frais” or, in the case of consumer prepackaged fresh vegetables, the expression “Stew-pack” or “légumes mixtes” or the expression “Vegetables for Stew” or “légumes pour ragoût”;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no one type of fresh fruit or vegetable in the container exceeds 1 kg net weight; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the net weight of the fresh fruits or vegetables in the container does not exceed 10 kg.

Section.MarginalNote: Fresh fruits or vegetables packaged with other food
Section.Text: The requirements of sections 113 to 121 and 269 — as well as any requirements under Division 2 of Part 10 and Part 12 that apply in respect of fresh fruits or vegetables — do not apply in respect of consumer prepackaged fresh fruits or vegetables if the container contains more than one type of fresh fruit or vegetable together with other food and if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the label that is applied or attached to the container bears the expression “Gift Pack” or “emballage-cadeau” or the expression “Combo Pack” or “emballage mixte”;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no one type of fresh fruit or vegetable in the container exceeds 1 kg net weight; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the net weight of the fresh fruits or vegetables and other food in the container does not exceed 10 kg.

Section.Text: The requirements of this Subdivision apply in respect of any fresh fruits or vegetables that are whole.

Subsection.Text: Potatoes that are imported must meet the requirements for the grade Canada No. 1 that are set out in the Compendium.

Potatoes that are imported from the United States are considered to meet the requirements for the grade Canada No. 1 that are set out in the Compendium if the potatoes have been graded in the United States and meet the applicable requirements that are set out in the document entitled Grade Standard Requirements for Fresh Fruits or Vegetables Imported from the United States, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time.

Section.MarginalNote: Apples from foreign state other than United States

Subsection.Text: Apples that are imported from a foreign state other than the United States must meet the requirements for the grade Canada Extra Fancy, Canada Fancy or Canada Commercial that are set out in the Compendium.
Apples that are imported from the United States must meet the requirements for the grade Canada Extra Fancy or Canada Fancy that are set out in the Compendium.

Apples that are imported from the United States are considered to meet the requirements for the grade Canada Extra Fancy or Canada Fancy that are set out in the Compendium if the apples have been graded in the United States and meet the applicable requirements that are set out in the document entitled Grade Standard Requirements for Fresh Fruits or Vegetables Imported from the United States, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time.

Section.Text: Fresh fruits or vegetables, other than potatoes or apples, that are imported from the United States are considered to meet the applicable requirements that are set out in the Compendium if the fruits or vegetables have been graded in the United States and meet the applicable requirements that are set out in the document entitled Grade Standard Requirements for Fresh Fruits or Vegetables Imported from the United States, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time.

Section.MarginalNote: Foreign states — onions, potatoes and apples
Section.Text: Onions and potatoes that are imported from a foreign state other than the United States, and apples that are imported from a foreign state other than the United States and New Zealand, must meet and be certified by the Minister as meeting the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicable requirements that are set out in Parts 10 to 12;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of onions, the requirements for a particular grade of onions that are set out in the Compendium;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of potatoes, the requirements for the grade Canada No. 1 that are set out in the Compendium; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of apples, the requirements for the grade Canada Extra Fancy, Canada Fancy or Canada Commercial that are set out in the Compendium.

Section.MarginalNote: Onions, potatoes and apples from United States

Subsection.Text: Onions, potatoes and apples that are imported from the United States must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied at the Canadian port of entry by a serially numbered certificate or evidence, in the form of a facsimile or a copy of an email message, issued by the federal department responsible for agriculture in the United States, that establishes that the following requirements are met:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicable requirements that are set out in Parts 10 to 12,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of onions, the requirements for a particular grade of onions that are set out in the Compendium,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of potatoes, the requirements for the grade Canada No. 1 that are set out in the Compendium, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of apples, the requirements for the grade Canada Extra Fancy or Canada Fancy that are set out in the Compendium; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet and be certified by the Minister as meeting the requirements that are set out in subparagraph (a)(i) and, in accordance with any general tolerances for inspection at the time of shipping or repackaging that are set out in the Compendium, the requirements that are set out in subparagraph (a)(ii), (iii) or (iv).

Subsection.Text: The certificate and evidence referred to in paragraph (1)(a) must be endorsed with the expression “Meets Canadian Import Requirements for Grades, Packaging, Labelling and Standard Container Size” or “satisfait aux exigences d’importation du Canada visant la classification, l’emballage, l’étiquetage et la taille des contenants normalisés”.
Apples that are imported from New Zealand must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied at the Canadian port of entry by a serially numbered certificate or evidence, in the form of a facsimile or a copy of an email message, issued by the ministry responsible for agriculture in New Zealand, that establishes that the following requirements are met:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicable requirements that are set out in Parts 10 to 12, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements for the grade Canada Extra Fancy, Canada Fancy or Canada Commercial that are set out in the Compendium; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet and be certified by the Minister as meeting the requirements that are set out in subparagraph (a)(i) and, in accordance with any general tolerances for inspection at the time of shipping or repackaging that are set out in the Compendium, the requirements that are set out in subparagraph (a)(ii).

Subsection.Text: The certificate and evidence referred to in paragraph (1)(a) must be endorsed with the expression “Meets Canadian Import Requirements for Grades, Packaging, Labelling and Standard Container Size” or “satisfait aux exigences d’importation du Canada visant la classification, l’emballage, l’étiquetage et la taille des contenants normalisés”.

Section.Text: Sections 116 to 118 do not apply in respect of onions, potatoes or apples that are part of a shipment that consists of not more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 15 containers of onions with an aggregate net weight of not more than 250 kg of onions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 15 containers of potatoes with an aggregate net weight of not more than 250 kg of potatoes; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 15 containers of apples with an aggregate net weight of not more than 250 kg of apples.

Section.Text: For the purposes of sections 113 to 119, if fresh fruits or vegetables are sent or conveyed to Canada in an in bond shipment from a foreign state other than the United States and pass only in transit through the United States, the fresh fruits or vegetables are not considered to have been imported from the United States.

Subsection.Text: An application for the issuance of a certificate referred to in section 116 or paragraph 117(1)(b) or 118(1)(b) must be made to the Minister in a form approved by the President.
The Minister may require an inspection for the purpose of deciding whether to issue the certificate.
If an inspection is required, the applicant must make the onions, potatoes or apples readily accessible to an inspector at the time of inspection.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION C
Heading.TitleText: Trade of Fresh Fruits or Vegetables

Subsection.Text: It is prohibited for a person to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sell any fresh fruits or vegetables that are to be exported or sent or conveyed from one province to another;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: purchase or negotiate the purchase on another person’s behalf of any fresh fruits or vegetables that are to be imported or sent or conveyed from one province to another;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: receive any fresh fruits or vegetables that have been imported or sent or conveyed from one province to another; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: send or convey from one province to another or import or export any fresh fruits or vegetables.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any person who is a member in good standing of the Fruit and Vegetable Dispute Resolution Corporation, a corporation incorporated under Part 2 of the Canada Not-for-profit Corporations Act, as described in its by-laws;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person who only sells fresh fruits or vegetables directly to consumers if that person paid less than $100,000 for the fresh fruits and vegetables that they sold to consumers within the previous 12 months;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any person who only purchases, sells or negotiates the purchase or sale on another person’s behalf, sends or conveys from one province to another or imports or exports less than one metric ton of fresh fruits and vegetables per day;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any person who only sells fresh fruits or vegetables that they have grown themselves; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a registered charity as defined in subsection 248(1) of the Income Tax Act or a club, society or association described in paragraph 149(1)(l) of that Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — nuts, wild fruit and wild vegetables
Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of nuts, wild fruit and wild vegetables.

Section.MarginalNote: Damaged or defective fresh fruits or vegetables

Subsection.Text: If a claim is made that all or part of a shipment of fresh fruits or vegetables that is imported or sent or conveyed from one province to another has arrived at its destination in a damaged or defective condition, any person who has a financial interest in that shipment may make a request to the Minister for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a written report that describes the condition of any damaged or defective fruits or vegetables at the time of the inspection; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a written notice of the disposition of any damaged or defective fresh fruits or vegetables that describes the amount of fresh fruit or vegetables that have been disposed of and the place and time of their disposal.

Subsection.Text: The request for a report or notice referred to in subsection (1) must be made to the Minister in a form approved by the President.

The person who makes the request for a report regarding the condition of fresh fruits or vegetables must make the fresh fruits or vegetables readily accessible to an inspector at the time of inspection.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Disposition of fresh fruit or vegetable
Subsection.Text: The person who makes the request for a notice regarding the disposition of damaged or defective fresh fruits or vegetables must ensure that their disposition is witnessed by an inspector.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: on-farm food safety program means a program in respect of food animals that is operated on a farm or at a similar place and under which hazards relating to the safety of meat products that may be derived from those food animals are identified, analyzed and controlled. (programme de salubrité des aliments à la ferme)
specified risk material has the same meaning as in section 6.1 of the Health of Animals Regulations. (matériel à risque spécifié)
split means to cut a carcass lengthwise along the median line. (fendre)
veterinary inspector means a person who is designated as a veterinary inspector under subsection 13(3) of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency Act for the purposes of the Act. (inspecteur vétérinaire)

Section.MarginalNote: Identification of meat products as edible

Subsection.Text: A licence holder may identify a meat product as edible only if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the food animal from which the meat product is derived, or a sample from the shipment that the food animal is part of, is subjected to an ante-mortem examination under section 138;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the food animal, other than a game animal, from which the meat product is derived, or a sample from the shipment that the food animal is part of, is subjected to an ante-mortem inspection under section 139;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the carcass of the food animal from which the meat product is derived is dressed or partially dressed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the carcass, its parts and the blood of the food animal from which the meat product is derived are subjected to a post-mortem inspection under subsection 149(1) or a post-mortem examination under subsection 150(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the meat product is edible and is not contaminated, including that it does not contain any specified risk material.

Subsection.Text: Despite (1), a licence holder must not identify as edible any of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a heart — other than the heart of a domesticated rabbit or of a bird that is not an ostrich, rhea or emu — unless it is opened or inverted and has all blood clots and attached blood vessels removed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a liver, unless the gallbladder is removed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a gizzard, unless its contents and lining are removed and the gizzard is washed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a meat product that contains a urinary bladder, an intestine or any part of a urinary bladder or intestine, unless the bladder, intestine or part is used as a natural casing for the meat product and meets the requirements of section 126; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a meat product with an artificial casing, unless the casing is manufactured from a material that is free of any noxious constituent.

Section.Text: A urinary bladder, an intestine or any part of a urinary bladder or intestine may be used as a natural casing for an edible meat product if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the bladder, the intestine or the part of the bladder or intestine have been emptied of their contents and washed, and their mucous lining has been removed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a bladder, it was inverted and placed in brine for at least 12 hours and was subsequently rinsed with water; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the casing is clean.

Section.Text: For greater certainty, a reference to an avoidable death in these Regulations does not include the slaughtering of a food animal in accordance with these Regulations or the humane killing of a food animal.

A licence holder must handle a food animal at the establishment in a manner that does not cause it avoidable suffering, injury or death and must not subject it to any condition that may cause such suffering, injury or death.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder must not hit a food animal with a whip, prod or, except for the purposes of section 141, any other object.
A licence holder must not apply an electric prod to a food animal unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is done for the purpose of causing the animal to move and there is no reasonably practicable alternative to the application of the prod;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the food animal is a pig or a bovine;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the prod is applied to the lateral portion of the rear leg muscles between the hock joint and the hip joint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the food animal has sufficient space to move forward;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the food animal’s ability to move is not compromised; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the prod is applied in a manner that does not cause the food animal avoidable suffering, injury or death.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder must assess whether a food animal is showing signs of suffering or injury on its arrival at the establishment.

After a food animal’s arrival, the licence holder must monitor it on a regular basis, including assessing the conditions to which the food animal is subjected in the establishment that may cause avoidable suffering, injury or death.
If the licence holder determines that conditions exist that may cause avoidable suffering, injury or death to a food animal, the licence holder must immediately take corrective action.
If a food animal is showing signs of suffering, the licence holder must immediately

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: alleviate its suffering;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: humanely kill it; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: slaughter it in accordance with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of a game animal.

Section.Text: A licence holder who has direct control over a game animal must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: monitor it on a regular basis, including assessing the conditions to which the game animal is subjected in the establishment that may cause avoidable suffering, injury or death;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: immediately take corrective action if such conditions exist; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the game animal is showing signs of suffering, immediately

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: alleviate its suffering,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: humanely kill it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: slaughter it in accordance with these Regulations.

Section.Text: A licence holder must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: segregate food animals of different species;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: segregate a sick or injured food animal with other sick or injured food animals or isolate a sick or injured food animal if, because of its condition, it presents a risk to other food animals or it requires protection from other food animals; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: isolate a food animal that may cause suffering, injury or death to other food animals because of its nature, temperament, gender, weight, age or any other cause.

Section.Text: A licence holder must provide a food animal with sufficient space to prevent the suffering of, injury to or death of the animal.
A licence holder must provide a food animal with sufficient ventilation to prevent the suffering of, injury to or death of the animal.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder who handles a food animal, including by handling a crate containing a food animal, during any activity they conduct in the establishment, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be able to do so, by reason of the person’s competencies and qualifications for the activity, without causing avoidable suffering, injury or death to the food animal; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: do so in a manner and under circumstances in which the equipment that is used will not cause avoidable suffering, injury or death to the food animal.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder must, during any activity conducted by the licence holder, use only areas of an establishment and equipment for the handling of a food animal that are designed, constructed and maintained in such a manner that they will not cause avoidable suffering, injury or death to the food animal.
A licence holder must provide a food animal — other than a food animal that is confined in a crate — that is unloaded from a conveyance at an establishment with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: water or another source of hydration as soon as it is unloaded; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: feed, within 24 hours after it is unloaded.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a food animal that is confined in a crate, the licence holder must provide the food animal with water or another source of hydration and with feed within 24 hours after it arrives at the establishment.
A licence holder must notify a veterinary inspector before a food animal is removed from an establishment.
A licence holder must notify a veterinary inspector before keeping a food animal in an establishment for more than seven days.

Within 24 hours before the slaughter of a food animal and in accordance with the document entitled Ante-mortem Examination and Presentation Procedures for Food Animals, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time, a licence holder must conduct an ante-mortem examination of the food animal or of a sample from the shipment that the food animal is part of, which must include, in the case an equine or a bird other than one that is a game animal or an ostrich, a rhea or an emu, the examination of the documents referred to in subsection 165(1).

If the licence holder, in the course of the ante-mortem examination or at any other time before slaughter, suspects that the food animal shows a deviation from normal behaviour, physiology or appearance, the licence holder must hold it for an inspection by a veterinary inspector, unless otherwise authorized by a veterinary inspector.

Within 24 hours before the slaughter of a food animal other than a game animal and in accordance with the document entitled Ante-mortem Examination and Presentation Procedures for Food Animals, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time, a licence holder must, for the purpose of an ante-mortem inspection, present the food animal or a sample from the shipment that the food animal is part of and, in the case of an equine or a bird other than an ostrich, rhea or emu, the documents referred to in subsection 165(1) to a veterinary inspector or inspector under the supervision of a veterinary inspector.

If an inspector who is not a veterinary inspector suspects that the food animal shows a deviation from normal behaviour, physiology or appearance, the licence holder must hold it for an inspection by a veterinary inspector.

Section.Text: If a veterinary inspector, or an inspector under the supervision of a veterinary inspector, determines after an inspection that any meat product that would be derived from a food animal could not be identified as edible under section 125 and condemns the food animal, a licence holder must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify the food animal as inedible;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: segregate the food animal with other condemned food animals or isolate the food animal if, because of its condition, it presents a risk to other food animals or it requires protection from other food animals;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: humanely kill the food animal; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identify the carcass and any blood collected from the food animal as inedible.

Section.Text: Before bleeding a food animal, other than a game animal, a licence holder must render it unconscious in a manner that prevents it from regaining consciousness before death or slaughter it by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: delivering a blow to the head with a mechanical device in a manner that causes an immediate loss of consciousness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: applying an electrical current in a manner that causes an immediate loss of consciousness; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: exposing it to a gas or a gas mixture in a manner that causes a rapid loss of consciousness.

Section.Text: A licence holder must not cut the carcass of a food animal after bleeding has started if it shows signs of sensibility that may indicate a potential return to consciousness.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder must not suspend a food animal before it is rendered unconscious or slaughtered in accordance with section 141, before it is ritually slaughtered in accordance with section 144 or before it is humanely killed.

Despite subsection (1), a licence holder may suspend a bird, other than an ostrich, rhea or emu, by its legs immediately before it is rendered unconscious or slaughtered in accordance with section 141 or immediately before it is humanely killed.

Section.Text: Despite section 141, a licence holder who ritually slaughters a food animal to comply with Judaic or Islamic law must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restrain the food animal;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: administer one continuous, fluid cut with a knife, without the knife being lifted off the food animal, resulting in the rapid, simultaneous and complete severance of the jugular veins and carotid arteries, in a manner that causes the animal to bleed immediately; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: rapidly and completely bleed it, to render it unconscious in a manner that prevents it from regaining consciousness before death.

Subsection.Text: After a food animal is bled, a licence holder must dress the carcass by doing the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the carcass of a pig,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: remove the hair, scurf, toenails and developed mammary glands or remove the skin, head, developed mammary glands and feet at the carpal and tarsal joints, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: eviscerate and split it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the carcass of a bird,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: remove the feathers and hair or remove the skin,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: remove the head, uropygial gland and feet at the tarsal joints, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: eviscerate it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the carcass of a goat,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: remove the hair, head, toenails and developed mammary glands or remove the skin, head, developed mammary glands and feet at the carpal and tarsal joints, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: eviscerate it; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the carcass of any other food animal,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: remove the skin, head, developed mammary glands and feet at the carpal and tarsal joints,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: eviscerate it, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: split it, except in the case of a sheep, calf or domesticated rabbit.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1) and at the request of the licence holder, the Minister must authorize the licence holder to partially dress a carcass if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder establishes that there is a market for partially dressed carcasses; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder’s procedure for partial dressing is such that the carcass is sufficiently dressed to enable a post-mortem examination or inspection.

Section.MarginalNote: Blood clots, bone splinters and extraneous matter
Section.Text: A licence holder must remove any blood clot, bone splinter and extraneous matter from the carcass of a food animal and the parts of the carcass, and must identify what was removed as inedible.
A licence holder must process a food animal’s blood in the inedible products area described in subsection 58(2) unless the licence holder

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: collects it in a manner that prevents contamination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: protects it against contamination after it is collected; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not defibrinate it by hand.

Section.Text: A licence holder must identify the blood of a food animal that is collected to be processed as an edible meat product and the parts of the carcass of the food animal in a manner that enables the correlation of the blood and the parts with the carcass from which they were removed until the completion of the post-mortem inspection or examination.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder must, during the course of dressing or partially dressing a carcass, present the carcass, its parts, and any blood of the food animal that is collected to be processed as an edible meat product to a veterinary inspector, or an inspector under the supervision of a veterinary inspector, for a post-mortem inspection.

A licence holder, other than a licence holder who is authorized to conduct a post-mortem defect management program, must not, before the post-mortem inspection is completed, remove from the carcass any part that shows a deviation from normal appearance unless authorized to do so by a veterinary inspector.

In the case of a licence holder who is authorized to conduct a post-mortem defect management program, the licence holder must not, before the post-mortem inspection begins, remove from the carcass any part that shows a deviation from normal appearance unless authorized to do so by a veterinary inspector.
This section does not apply to a licence holder who is authorized to conduct a post-mortem examination program under subsection 160(3).

During the course of dressing or partially dressing a carcass, a licence holder who is authorized to conduct a post-mortem examination program under subsection 160(3) must, under the supervision of a veterinary inspector, conduct a post-mortem examination of the carcass, its parts and the blood of the food animal that has been collected to be processed as an edible meat product.

During the course of dressing or partially dressing a carcass, a licence holder who is authorized to conduct a post-mortem defect management program under subsection 160(3) must, under the supervision of a veterinary inspector, do the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the post-mortem inspection begins, conduct a post-mortem screening of the carcass, its parts and the blood of the food animal that has been collected to be processed as an edible meat product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before the post-mortem inspection of the carcass is completed, implement the necessary measures with respect to any defects of the carcass or its parts.

Section.Text: In the case of an edible dressed or partially dressed whole carcass or an edible dressed carcass side, other than a carcass or carcass side of a domesticated rabbit or a bird that is not an ostrich, rhea or emu, the inspection legend must be applied after the post-mortem inspection or examination and before refrigeration

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by stamping it directly onto the carcass or carcass side; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by applying a label to the carcass or carcass side that is shown prominently and that bears the inspection legend, the date of slaughter of the food animal from which the carcass or carcass side is derived and a code that enables the carcass or carcass side to be correlated with the slaughter of the food animal.

Section.Text: If a veterinary inspector, or an inspector under the supervision of a veterinary inspector, determines after a post-mortem inspection that any meat product that would be derived from a carcass, any of its parts or the blood of the food animal could not be identified as edible under section 125 and condemns the carcass, its parts or the blood of the food animal, a licence holder must identify any meat product that is derived from the condemned carcass, parts or blood as inedible.
A licence holder must identify as inedible

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the carcass, any of its parts or the blood of a food animal that is rejected by the licence holder who is authorized to conduct a post-mortem examination program or a post-mortem defect management program under subsection 160(3); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the carcass of a food animal that dies other than by slaughter in accordance with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: A licence holder may treat as inedible any meat product that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: does not have its movement restricted by an inspector; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has its movement restricted by an inspector if the licence holder obtains an inspector’s authorization to move the meat product to the inedible products area described in subsection 58(2).

Subsection.Text: The licence holder must identify as inedible any meat product that the licence holder treats as inedible.
When a meat product is condemned or identified as inedible, a licence holder must move it directly to the inedible products area described in subsection 58(2).
The licence holder must take one of the following measures in respect of a meat product that is moved to the inedible products area:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: apply or attach a label to it that indicates its intended use and bears the expression “Not for Use as Human Food” or “ne peut servir à l’alimentation humaine”; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dispose of it in accordance with section 66.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (2), the licence holder must keep a meat product that is a specified risk material, contains a specified risk material or is derived from a specified risk material in a separate area of the inedible products area and must handle and destroy it in accordance with Part I.1 of the Health of Animals Regulations.

Section.Text: A licence holder must take one of the following measures in respect of a contaminated meat product:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject it to a treatment or process that eliminates the contamination; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify it as inedible.

Section.Text: A licence holder may identify as edible a meat product that is derived from a pig and that does not require further preparation before consumption, other than washing or thawing or exposing it to sufficient heat to warm it without cooking it, only if the conditions for identifying the meat product as edible under section 125 are met and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pork is subjected to a treatment or process that inactivates Trichinella spp. viable larvae;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pork is derived from a carcass that tests negative for the detection of Trichinella spp. larvae using a method that is shown by evidence to be effective; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the pig originates from a farm that operates an on-farm food safety program under which the risk of Trichinella spp. infection is negligible.

Section.Text: A licence holder may identify as edible a meat product that is derived from an equine only if the conditions for identifying the meat product as edible under section 125 are met and the equine’s carcass tests negative for the detection of Trichinella spp. larvae using a method that is shown by evidence to be effective.

A licence holder may identify as edible a meat product that is derived from a bovine whose carcass is affected by or shows evidence of bovine cysticercosis only if the conditions for identifying the meat product as edible under section 125 are met and the licence holder has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: removed the parts of the carcass that are affected and identified them as inedible; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subjected the remaining parts to a treatment or process that inactivates bovine cysticercosis viable larvae.

Subsection.Text: The holder of a licence to slaughter may apply in writing to the Minister for an authorization to conduct

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a post-mortem examination program concerning a food animal referred to in the document entitled Fundamentals of the Post-mortem Examination Program, prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a post-mortem defect management program concerning a food animal referred to in the document entitled Fundamentals of the Post-mortem Defect Management Program prepared by the Agency and published on its website, as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: The application must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder’s licence number and the address of the establishment where the program will be conducted; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the licence holder’s preventive control plan that meets the requirements of section 89.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must authorize the licence holder to conduct a post-mortem examination program or a post-mortem defect management program if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the preventive control plan that is included in the licence holder’s application meets the requirements of section 89; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister is of the opinion, based on the information that was made available to him or her, that the licence holder is able to conduct the program in compliance with these Regulations.

Section.Text: The Minister may suspend a licence holder’s authorization to conduct a post-mortem examination program or a post-mortem defect management program if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder does not comply with their post-mortem examination program or post-mortem defect management program;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder does not comply with any provision of the Act or of these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister is of the opinion that a risk of injury to human health may result if the licence holder continues to conduct the program.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must not suspend a licence holder’s authorization to conduct a post-mortem examination program or a post-mortem defect management program unless the licence holder

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: was provided with an inspection report that sets out the grounds for the suspension and the period within which corrective action must be taken in order to avoid the suspension; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: failed to take corrective action within that period.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must notify the licence holder in writing of the suspension and the date on which it takes effect.

Section.MarginalNote: Risk of injury to human health

Subsection.Text: Despite section 162, if the Minister is of the opinion that a risk of injury to human health may result if the licence holder continues to conduct the post-mortem examination program or post-mortem defect management program, the Minister may suspend the authorization immediately after the licence holder is provided with an inspection report that sets out the grounds for the suspension.
The Minister must notify the licence holder in writing that their authorization is suspended and that the suspension takes effect immediately.

Section.Text: The suspension of an authorization to conduct a post-mortem examination program or post-mortem defect management program must be lifted if the Minister determines that corrective action has been taken.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION K
Heading.TitleText: Food Animal Information Documents and Document Keeping

Subsection.Text: Before slaughtering a food animal that is an equine or a bird, the holder of a licence to slaughter must obtain, from the person who owned or had the possession, care or control of the food animal before its arrival at the establishment where it is intended to be slaughtered, documents that include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person who owned it and any person who had the possession, care or control of it immediately before its arrival at the establishment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the last location where it was raised or kept before its arrival at the establishment, including the address of the location, its code or the number that identifies it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the food animal’s identification number or any other information that identifies it;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any on-farm food safety program under which the food animal was raised or kept;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a bird,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the time at which the first bird of the lot of birds was placed into a crate,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the time at which the bird was last provided with access to a source of hydration before being loaded, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the time at which the bird was last provided with access to feed before being loaded;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
